Das, J., observed at p. 299 In determining the question of the validity or otherwise of a statute the companyrt will number strike down the law Out of had only because numberclassification appears on its face or because a discretion is given to the Government to make the selection or classification but will go on to examine and ascertain if the statute has laid down any principle or policy for the guidance of the exercise of discretion or classification.

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of res judicata does not apply so as to make a decision on a question of fact or law in a proceeding for assessment in one year binding in another year.

arguments.claim: s. 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act invested the Income-tax Officer with arbitrary and unguided power to assess to tax the income of an association of persons in the hands either of the association or of the persons constituting that association, and on that account offended Art. 14

anchor.surface_text: In support of the petitions it was urged that s. 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act invested the Income-tax Officer with arbitrary and unguided power to assess to tax the income of an association of persons in the hands either of the association or of the persons const

court_response_anchor.surface_text: plicable to analogous or companyparable situations or generally from the object sought to be achieved by the enactment. Section 3 of the Income-tax Ac

arguments.court_reasoning: Discretion guided by duty to prevent tax evasion, quasi-judicial, appealable; policy from Act's scheme; distinguishes Suraj Mall as no drastic procedure difference

arguments.claim: The Act sets out no principles and discloses no guidance to the Income-tax Officer in exercising the option conferred by s.3, therefore confers arbitrary and uncontrolled authority

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Income-tax Act invests the taxing authority with an option to assess to tax the income collectively of the association of persons, in the hands of the association or in separate shares in the hands of the members of the association. Counsel for the assessee contends that the Act sets out no principles and discloses no guidance to the Income-tax Officer in exercising the option the Act therefore confers arbitrary and uncontrolled authority upon the Income-tax Officer to select either the association or its members for assessment to tax according to his fancy, and may on that account be discriminatively administered by subjecting persons similarly situate to varying rates of tax.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in selecting the association or the members individually as entities in bringing to tax the income earned by the association. Guidance may still be ga

arguments.court_reasoning: Guidance from Act's scheme, policy to prevent evasion, quasi-judicial nature, appeals available; cites Dalmia and Jyoti Pershad on implied policy

arguments.claim: S.23A repeal by Act 7 of 1939 removed principles guiding ITO discretion under s.3, leaving it unfettered

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants contended that s. 23-A of the Income-tax Act, as it was incorporated by Act 21 of 1930, laid down certain principles for the guidance of the Income- tax Officer in exercising his option, but since the Legislature by Act 7 of 1939 repealed that provision the discretion vested in the Income-tax Officer to select either the income of the association or the individual members is unfettered.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tner was to be separately taken into account together with his other income and brought to tax. If it was an unregistered firm, the income of the firm

arguments.court_reasoning: Repeal did not alter essential nature; policy to prevent evasion continues; analogous to unregistered firms under s.23(5)(b)

arguments.claim: There was no association of persons in 1951-52 as no agreement or assent by/on behalf of minor Chettiappa

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the assessee urged that there was no association in fact that Chettiappa being at all material times a minor there could in law be no association of which the income could be brought to tax, and that in any event there was no evidence to prove that any one on behalf of Chettiappa had assented to the formation of the association.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ued undisturbed right throughout the period, only the holding thereof by various members having changed from time to time. The volition necessary is o

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted for 1951-52 by HC, but SC defers to Tribunal/HC on later years; evidence of common management, books, assent by guardian

arguments.claim: Once no AOP in 1951-52, no AOP in subsequent years without positive evidence of new formation

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the assessee contends that once the High Court reached the conclusion that in the year 1951-52 there was no association of persons, the conclusion that an association of persons existed in the subsequent years could not be reached in the absence of positive evidence to show that after the close of the year 1951-52 an association of persons was actually formed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rly show that there was such an association in the years 1952-53 and the subsequent years. Pursuant to the three partitions numberdivision by metes an

arguments.court_reasoning: Different associations each year; res judicata does not apply across years; evidence supports for 1952-53 onwards (Chokalingam share demand, common management)

arguments.claim: No materials to hold assessee (Meyyappa I) as principal officer of M.M. Ipoh AOP

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, there are any materials to hold the assessee as the principal officer of M.M. Ipoh assessed in the status of an association of persons?

court_response_anchor.surface_text: eals to companysider whether the learned Judges of the High Court were right in the view which they have taken insofar as it relates to the assessment

arguments.court_reasoning: Notices served implying intention; assessment orders state returns filed by him as PO; no prior objection; sufficient materials

arguments.claim: Before issuing notice for assessment of AOP, ITO must first issue notice of intention and pass order treating person as PO

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the assessee contended that there were no materials on which the Tribunal could hold that Meyyappa I was the principal officer of M.M. Ipoh, and since the Income-tax Officer had made no enquiry before issuing the notice treating Meyyappa I was the principal officer of M.M. Ipoh, Meyyappa I could not be so treated for the purpose of the proceedings for assessment.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t may be good and companyent evidence in subsequent years, when the same question falls to be determined in another year, but they are number binding

arguments.court_reasoning: s.2(12)(b) allows service of notice of intention to treat as PO; no prior order needed before assessment notice; analogous to s.43 agent; cites JC precedent

arguments.claim: Assessments on AOP for 1951-52 to 1956-57 invalid

arguments.claim: s.3 does not confer arbitrary power; discretion guided by policy to prevent evasion, quasi-judicial, appealable; not violative of Art14

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Income-tax Act invests the taxing authority with an option... The nature of the authority exercised by the Income-tax Officer in a proceeding to assess to tax income, and his duty to prevent evasion or escapement of liability to pay tax legitimately due to the State, constitute, in our judgment, adequate enunciation of principles and policy for the guidance of the Income-tax Officer.

arguments.claim: Suraj Mall precedent does not apply as no difference in procedure or rights; same assessment process whether AOP or members

anchor.surface_text: Counsel in support of that plea relied upon the judgment of this Court in Suraj Mall Mohta Co. v. A. V. Visvanatha Sastri... but that case is of little assistance to the assessee... here no question of application of a more drastic procedure, or deprivation of valuable rights of appeal and revision, by the adoption of one of two alternative procedures arises.

arguments.claim: Policy/guidance implied from Act's preamble, scheme, other provisions, duty to prevent evasion (Dalmia, Jyoti Pershad)

anchor.surface_text: In Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia... In determining the question of the validity... the court will go on to examine... if the statute has laid down any principle or policy... It is not however essential... that the rules for the guidance should be laid down in express terms. Such guidance may be obtained from... the policy and purpose of the enactment...

arguments.claim: AOP existed in 1952-57: common purpose, management by MSMM firm, books, selling agency; minor can join; guardian assent inferred

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax... the word associate means to join in common purpose... there is abundant material, to prove that Meyyappa I, his minor son Chettiappa and M.S.M.M. firm formed an association... common management... Alagammal... acted as guardian... Tribunal found assent.

arguments.claim: Res judicata does not apply across assessment years; findings relevant but not conclusive

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of res judicata does not apply so as to make a decision on a question of fact or law in a proceeding for assessment in one year binding in another year. The assessment and the facts found are conclusive only in the year of assessment...

arguments.claim: Firm is 'person'; can form AOP with individuals including minors

anchor.surface_text: The expression person is defined in s. 2(9)... inclusive... Clause (42) of s. 3 of the General Clauses Act defines a person as inclusive of any company, association or body of individuals... A firm is therefore a Person within the meaning of the Income-tax Act...

arguments.claim: No prior order declaring PO needed; notice under s.22/34/63 suffices; analogous to s.43 agent (JC precedent)

anchor.surface_text: There is in the Income-tax Act an analogous provision in s. 43... it is not necessary... that it should have been preceded not only by the notice of intimation prescribed by s. 43, but also by an order declaring the person to be agent... The same principle applies...

arguments.claim: Income from houses assessed individually under s.9, not collectively as AOP

anchor.surface_text: In appeals filed by M. M. Ipoh, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the orders passed by the Income-tax Officer subject to the modification that the income from the houses be assessed under s. 9(3) of the Income-tax Act in the hands of the members individually, and not as the collective, income of the association of persons.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: accrued to an association of persons formed by Meyyappa  1 , S.M.M. firm and the minor Chettiappa.

arguments.claim: Meyyappa I is principal officer; notices served, returns filed, no objection till Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The High Court recorded in answer to the second question that the Income-tax Officer was justified in holding Meyyappa I to be the principal officer of M.M. Ipoh.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: anagement of the properties, and there was even a companymon. selling agency.Alagammal had acted as a guardian of Chettiappa in the deed of partition.

arguments.claim: AOP in 1952-57: Meyyappa I acted for Chettiappa; unity of purpose, management

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the income... in the years 1952-53 to 1956-57 accrued to an association of persons formed by Meyyappa I, S.M.M. firm and the minor Chettiappa... unity purpose and objectivity...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mother of Chettiappa-had executed the deed of partition dated April 13, 1950 as the guardian of Chettiappa. By the deed she acknowledged having receiv

holdings.text: It cannot therefore be said that there is, by investing authority in the Income-tax Officer to select the association of persons or individual members thereof for the purpose of assessing to tax the income of the association, denial of equality before the law between persons similarly situate within the meaning of Art. 14 of the Constitution so as to render s. 3 insofar as it confers power upon the Income-tax Officer to select either the association of persons or the members thereof for assessment to tax in respect of the income of the association void.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot therefore be said that there is, by investing authority in the Income-tax Officer to select the association of persons or individual members thereof for the purpose of assessing to tax the income of the association, denial of equality before the law between persons similarly situate within the meaning of Art. 14 of the Constitution so as to render s. 3

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion under s.3 guided by Act's scheme, duty to prevent tax evasion, quasi-judicial nature, appeals available; policy implied from provisions like s.23(5)(b); follows Dalmia and Jyoti Pershad tests; distinguishes Suraj Mall.

holdings.text: The facts proved clearly show that there was an association of persons in the years 1952-53 and the subsequent years formed by Meyyappa I, the M.S.M.M. firm and Chettiappa.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the facts proved clearly show that there was such an association in the years 1952-53 and the subsequent years. Pursuant to the three partitions no division by metes and bounds of the shares of the owners was made, only the shares in the income of the owner were entered in the books of account.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Abundant evidence of common purpose, management by M.S.M.M. firm, common books and selling agency; assent by guardian Alagammal inferred from partition deed and entrustment; Tribunal finding of fact upheld.

holdings.text: The doctrine of res judicata does not apply so as to make a decision on a question of fact or law in a proceeding for assessment in one year binding in another year.

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of res judicata does not apply so as to make a decision on a question of fact or law in a proceeding for assessment in one year binding in another year. The assessment and the facts found are conclusive only in the year of assessment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Each assessment year independent; prior findings relevant evidence but not conclusive or binding across years.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer was justified in holding Meyyappa I to be the principal officer of M.M. Ipoh.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court recorded in answer to the second question that the Income-tax Officer was justified in holding Meyyappa I to be the principal officer of M.M. Ipoh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notices served on him implying intention; returns filed by him as PO; assessment orders record him as PO; no prior objection; sufficient materials per Tribunal/High Court upheld.

holdings.text: There is nothing in the Act which supports the contention that before proceedings in assessment can commence against an association of persons a notice must in the first instance be issued and an order passed after giving opportunity to the person proposed to be treated as the principal officer opportunity to show cause why he should not be so treated.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our judgment, nothing in the Act which supports the contention of counsel for the assessee that before proceedings in assessment can commence against an association of persons a notice must in the first instance be issued and an order passed after giving opportunity to the person proposed to be treated as the principal officer

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(12)(b) deems PO upon service of notice of intention; no prior order required before assessment notice; analogous to s.43 statutory agent per JC precedent; status determinable during assessment, appealable.

holdings.text: A firm is therefore a Person within the meaning of the Income-tax Act, and a firm and an individual or group of individuals may form an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The expression person is defined in s. 2 9 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 as including a Hindu undivided family and a local authority. The definition is inclusive and resort may appropriately be had to the General Clauses Act to ascertain the meaning of the expression person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inclusive definition in s.2(9) IT Act; s.3(42) General Clauses Act includes firm as body of individuals; applied to allow firm in AOP.

holdings.text: There is nothing, in the Act which indicates that a minor cannot become a member of an association of persons for the purposes of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing, in the Act which indicates that a minor cannot become a member of an association of persons for the purposes of the Act. In Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay Laxmidas and Anr. it was held that the fact that one of the individuals was a minor did not affect the existence of the association,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prohibition in Act; precedents confirm minor membership ok if association for income production; guardian assent suffices.

precedents.citation: Suraj Mall Mohta Co. v. A. V. Visvanatha Sastri and Anr. 1

anchor.surface_text: Suraj Mall Mohta Co. v. A. V. Visvanatha Sastri and Anr. 1 but that case is of little assistance to the assessee. In Suraj Mall Mohtas cave 1 this Court declared sub-s.  4  of s. 5 of the Taxation of Income  Investigation Commission  Act 30 of 1947

precedents.case_name: Suraj Mall Mohta & Co. v. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri
precedents.cited_proposition: sub-s. (4) of s. 5 of the Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947 invalid as discriminatory legislation offending Art. 14
precedents.cited_holding: sub-s. (4) of s. 5 of Act 30 of 1947 dealt with same class as s.34 IT Act but more drastic procedure

anchor.surface_text: In Suraj Mall Mohtas cave 1 this Court declared sub-s.  4  of s. 5 of the Taxation of Income  Investigation Commission  Act 30 of 1947 and the procedure prescribed by that Act, insofar as it affected the persons proceeded against under that sub-section, invalid as a piece of discriminatory legislation

precedents.case_name: Suraj Mall Mohta & Co. v. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri
precedents.cited_proposition: procedure under Investigation Commission Act more drastic than s.34 IT Act leading to discriminatory treatment

precedents.citation: Shri Rain Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar and Ors, 1

anchor.surface_text: In Shri Rain Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar and Ors, 1 S. R. Das, J., observed at p. 299 In determining the question of the validity or otherwise of a statute the companyrt will number strike down the law Out of had only because numberclassification appears on its face or because a discretion is given to the Government to make the selection or classification

precedents.case_name: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar
precedents.cited_proposition: court examines if statute lays down principle or policy for guidance in exercise of discretion; strikes down if arbitrary
precedents.cited_holding: statute providing delegation of arbitrary power enabling discrimination is invalid

precedents.citation: Jyoti Pershad v. The Administrator for the Union Terri- tory of Delhi 1

anchor.surface_text: In Jyoti Pershad v. The Administrator for the Union Terri- tory of Delhi 1 this Court observed that where the Legislature Jays down the policy and indicates the rule or line of action which should guide the authority, Art. 14 is number violated, unless the rules or the policy indicated lay down different criteria to be applied to persons or things similarly situate.

precedents.case_name: Jyoti Pershad v. Administrator for the Union Territory of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Legislature need not expressly lay down guidance; may be from preamble, circumstances, other provisions or object of enactment

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. v. Kanpur Coal Syndicate 1

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. v. Kanpur Coal Syndicate 1  it was held by this Court that the Appellate Tribunal has ample power under s. 33 4  to set aside an assessment made on an association of persons and to direct the Income-tax Officer to assess the members individually or to direct amendment of the assessment already made on the members.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. v. Kanpur Coal Syndicate
precedents.cited_proposition: Appellate Tribunal has power to set aside assessment on association and direct assessment on individual members
precedents.cited_holding: Tribunal's power under s.33(4) to be exercised judicially

anchor.surface_text: The policy and the purpose of the Act may be gathered from other operative provisions applicable to analogous or companyparable situations Jyoti Pershads case 1  at p. 139 and there can  1  1962 2 S.C.R. 125. be numberdoubt that an unregistered firm and an association of persons are closely analogous.

precedents.case_name: Jyoti Pershad v. Administrator for the Union Territory of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: policy gathered from other provisions applicable to analogous situations

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay Laxmidas and Anr. 1

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay Laxmidas and Anr.  1  it was held that the fact that one of the  1  1937 I.T.R. 584. individuals was a minor did number affect the existence of the association, if in point of fact, the assessees had associated together for the purpose of gain.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas
precedents.cited_proposition: minor member does not affect existence of association of persons if they associated for purpose of gain

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay North, Kutch and Saurashtra v.Indira Balkrishna 1

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay North, Kutch and Saurashtra v.Indira Balkrishna 1  it was held that the word associate means to join in companymon purpose, or to join in an action. Therefore, and association of persons must be one in which two or more persons join in a companymon purpose or companymon action, 1 1960 39 I.T.R. 546.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay North, Kutch and Saurashtra v. Indira Balkrishna
precedents.cited_proposition: "associate" means to join in common purpose or action, with object to produce income

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab W.F.P. v. Nawal Kishore Kharaiti Lai 1

anchor.surface_text: It was held by the Judicial Committee in Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab W.F.P. v. Nawal Kishore Kharaiti Lai 1  that it is number necessary for the validity of a numberice calling for a return of the income under S. 23 2  served on a person as agent of a number-resident under S. 43, that it should have been preceded number only by the numberice of intimation prescribed by s. 43, but also by an order declaring the person to be agent of the number-resident or treating him as such.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab W.F.P. v. Nawal Kishore Kharaiti Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: no prior order required before serving notice on agent under s.43; can be determined at assessment
precedents.cited_holding: Income-tax Officer may postpone determination of agency status until assessment

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
